text: Mr. Bernoski saved examples of subtraction equations that his class used in Investigation 1. He put up the posters. He challenges his students to look for patterns. Record equations from Investigation 1 that fit in each category.

• How can you predict whether the difference of two integers is negative, positive, or equal to zero? Explain your reasoning using equations, number lines, or chip boards.
  • What strategy can you use to find the difference? Does it work in each case? Explain.

Student answers will include a variety of thinking. Many students will answer with cases using the model for thinking about subtraction. See the following examples.

Differences that equal zero

If the integers have the same absolute value and the same signs, then their difference is 0. This is what happens on a chip board when you have an amount and you take away that amount.

Differences that do not equal zero

Number Line Reasoning: Some students will consider the value of the numbers.

The size of the numbers determine if the difference will be smaller than, larger than, or equal to 0.

  • Larger # subtract a Smaller # is positive (Student will say things like, “You have enough to subtract, so you don’t go in the negative.”)
  • Smaller # subtract a Larger # is negative (Student will say things like, “You don’t have enough to subtract, so you will need to go into the negative.”)

With a number line, the distance the numbers are apart will determine the value of the positive or negative amounts (difference)

–4 - 3 = ?

The distance from 3 to –4 is 7 units

Distances on the number line cannot be negative. So, we need to think about the size of the numbers to determine if the difference is negative or positive:

Smaller# – Larger# = negative

So, –4 - 3 = –7

With the number line, some students may use fact family reasoning.

The original equation –4 – 3 = n can be thought of as 3 + n = -4. The change, n, is the difference between the numbers. Students will then reason about the distance being 7 and the change from 3 to -4 is -7.

Chip Model Reasoning

With the chips, if there is ‘not enough’ to subtract, you need to add a quantity for zero.

In this example, you add (–3 + 3), so there are 3 positives to subtract. With addition using the chips, you show both addends on the board. With subtraction, you show the minuend and take away the subtrahend.

Money Reasoning

With money, 4 was borrowed (-4). Then another three was taken away (subtracted) from the total, so now there is 7 borrowed, or -7.

Going Positive Game Reasoning

In a game like Going Positive, if you got questions wrong and had a score of –4, then 3 more is taken from your score for more incorrect answers, you would have a score of –7.

Note: students may not include all of these cases, or may explain using different models.
